sources.title: Evidence
sources.placeholder: Add Sources for publication to class

text: Below are the Resources for the current Chapter of the story and cumulative resources for the previous chapters. When you are ready for your students to have access to the resources for the current chapter, make them available in the students' Resource Library tab as follows:

1. Drag the tiles below into your Log on the right, placing them at the top (above the previous chapter's resources).
  2. Note: you can multi-select tiles by holding down the shift key when clicking them
  3. Click the Publish button (blue rectangle with the up arrow, to the left of Log title)
  4. Go to the Resource Library tab (pink) and delete your previously published resources, leaving only the newest published material
Your students will now see the cumulative Resources under their Resource Library tab.
Evidence 1: The Effects of Stress on the Heart (video)
Questions About Evidence 1, The Effects of Stress on the Heart (video)
3. Both monkeys had the same diet and health care, the difference in their blood vessels is only due to the stress from social subordination.
Welcome to the Bio4Community CLUE Teacher Guide
Each small group in your classroom will read one of the three Bio4Community Stress Stories.

To get started, create a class for each small group in the Concord portal. You will create a unique access code for your students, called the "Class Word". Give each group their class word and have them register for accounts at https://learn.concord.org. Then contact Frieda (freichsman@concord.org) who will assign the chapters for the stories to each group for you. You will then be able to release each Chapter to each group in sequence.

Each chapter of the three stories (Rakesh, Estrella, and Felix) is accompanied by a Resource Library for students. When you are ready, you will publish the list so the students can see it and access the Resources.
To publish the Resource Library List for each Chapter:

• Drag the list from your Resource Library tab (left side of screen) to your Workspace (right-hand side of screen)
  • There you can edit the list, if you wish, before publishing them to the Class.
  • Click the Publish button at the upper left of the Workspace. Note: everything in your Workspace will be published to the students' Resource Library tab. Make sure to tailor the Workspace to what you want to publish.

Tell the students that we are trying something a bit different. Instead of just giving them evidence in a packet like we did for short term stress, we are giving them a story, and different groups have different stories. The stories follow a main character as they try to figure out a health issue that is making them concerned. The characters encounter evidence along the way and use it to figure out the issue.
They should work as a team and assign the cast. The narrator has a lot to read. Other roles have much less.
They should answer the questions and fill in the table in their Workspace.
Questions About Evidence 2a, All the Fuss About Cholesterol (blog post)
1. Our body can make all the cholesterol we need.
2. Cholesterol is needed to build cells, make vitamins, and make hormones.
3. A cholesterol plaque can form in:

• A. The liver
  • B. Inside the blood vessel wall
  • C. The stomach
1. Low long-term stress levels result in faster plaque formation.
2. The cells that are formed when immune cells “eat up” cholesterol are called ________.
• A. Yellow cells        B. Foam cells      C. Red cells
3. When there is high cholesterol in diet more foam cells form.
Evidence 1: The Effects of Stress on the Heart (video)
<h2>Welcome to the Bio4Community CLUE Teacher Guide!<h2>

Each small group in your classroom will read one of the three Bio4Community Stress Stories, about Rakesh, Estrella, or Felix. The stories are accessed through the Concord Portal at https://learn.concord.org.
To get started, register as a teacher and log into the Concord Portal Then, follow these steps:

1. Create a class for each small group in the Concord portal.
  2. Create a unique access code for each group of students, called the "class word"
  3. Give each group their class word and have them register for student accounts.
  4. Contact Frieda (freichsman@concord.org) who will assign the chapters for the stories to each group for you.
  5. You will then be able to release each Chapter to each group when you are ready for them to have access..

Each chapter of the three stories (Rakesh, Estrella, and Felix) is accompanied by a Resource Library for students. When you are ready, you will publish the Resource Library list so the students can see it and access the Resources.
To publish the Resource Library List for each Chapter:
• Drag all the tiles from your Evidence tab (left side of screen, under Curriculum) to your Workspace (right-hand side of screen)
Note: you can multi-select tiles by holding down the shift key when clicking them

• Edit the list, if you wish
  • Click the blue Publish button (rectangle with up arrow) at the upper left of the Workspace
  • Note: everything in your Workspace will be published to the students' Resource Library tab when you click the button. Make sure to delete any tiles that are not part of the Resource List

Tell the students that we are trying something a bit different. Instead of just giving them evidence in a packet like we did for short term stress, we are giving them a story, and different groups have different stories. The stories follow a main character as they try to figure out a health issue that is making them concerned. The characters encounter evidence along the way and use it to figure out the issue.
They should work as a team and assign the cast. The narrator has a lot to read. Other roles have much less.
They should answer the questions and fill in the table in their Workspace.
Question About Evidence 3, Rakesh Sharma Blood Test Report
1. Rakesh’s cholesterol levels are? (underline your choice)

Tell the students that we are trying something a bit different. Instead of just giving them evidence in a packet like we did for short term stress, we are giving them a story, and different groups have different stories. The stories follow a main character as they try to figure out a health issue that is making them concerned. The characters encounter evidence along the way and use it to figure out the issue.
They should work as a team and assign the cast. The narrator has a lot to read. Other roles have much less.
They should answer the questions and fill in the table in their Workspace.
1. When immune cell signaling is high it causes less immune cells to come into the lining and less sticky proteins to appear.
2. When cortisol levels are high but the cortisol is ignored this causes the plaque to form:

• A. allow cholesterol into the lining
  • B. allow immune cells into the lining
  • C. block the entry of immune cells into the lining
  • D. block the entry of cholesterol into the lining
Questions About Evidence 5a and 5c, Conversation with Dr. Zeiders and Missing Link Report

• White blood cells
  • Red blood cells
  • White blood cells after engulfing cholesterol
2. Normally cortisol prevents immune cells from getting into the blood vessel and making the plaque bigger.
3. If cortisol is high for a long time the body starts to ignore it.

  4. Contact Frieda (freichsman@concord.org) who will assign the chapters for the stories to each group for you.
  5. You will then be able to release each Chapter to each group when you are ready for them to have access..

Each chapter of the three stories (Rakesh, Estrella, and Felix) is accompanied by a Resource Library for students. When you are ready, you will publish the Resource Library list so the students can see it and access the Resources.
To publish the Resource Library List for each Chapter:
• Drag all the tiles from your Evidence tab (left side of screen, under Curriculum) to your Workspace (right-hand side of screen)
Note: you can multi-select tiles by holding down the shift key when clicking them

• Edit the list, if you wish
  • Click the blue Publish button (rectangle with up arrow) at the upper left of the Workspace
  • Note: everything in your Workspace will be published to the students' Resource Library tab when you click the button. Make sure to delete any tiles that are not part of the Resource List

Tell the students that we are trying something a bit different. Instead of just giving them evidence in a packet like we did for short term stress, we are giving them a story, and different groups have different stories. The stories follow a main character as they try to figure out a health issue that is making them concerned. The characters encounter evidence along the way and use it to figure out the issue.
They should work as a team and assign the cast. The narrator has a lot to read. Other roles have much less.
They should answer the questions and fill in the table in their Workspace.
